required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Mohs Micrographic Surgery and Reconstruction in the Optum Insurance Claims Database
clinical_study.official_title: Characterizing Trends in Mohs Micrographic Surgery and Complex Reconstruction in the Optum Healthcare Population

brief_summary.textblock: Mohs micrographic surgery (MMS) followed by skin reconstruction has been widely accepted for treatment of many skin cancers. To further characterize the trends in MMS and reconstruction for skin cancer, a retrospective analysis will be performed using the Optum© Clinformatics® DataMart de-identified commercial claims database from 2001-2016. The findings may provide critical data for future prospective studies in skin cancer treatments.

clinical_study.why_stopped: The researchers were unable to answer the study question by utilizing the insurance claims database.

primary_outcome.description: How does interpolation flap procedure cost differ across settings

secondary_outcome.measure: Predictors of inpatient vs. outpatient procedure
secondary_outcome.description: How does medical specialty or geographical location predict where the procedure is performed

arm_group.description: Patients from the existing Optum insurance claimed database with a confirmed diagnosis of melanoma, basal cell carcinoma, or squamous cell carcinoma who have undergone skin cancer excision surgery followed by interpolated flap repair between the years 2001-2006.

study_pop.textblock: The study population was conveniently sampled from the compilation of de-identified claims in the Optum© Clinformatics® database using ICD9 and ICD10 codes specific for skin cancer and linking them to specific CPT codes for interpolated flap repair, a reconstructive skin surgery. The investigator's population is composed of >7,000 patients across the United States who received a skin cancer diagnosis and this procedure between 2001 and 2016.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion criteria:
- All patients in the Optum© Clinformatics® database who have an ICD9 or ICD10 code for skin cancer and a corresponding CPT code specific for interpolated flap reconstruction
Exclusion criteria:
- All patients for whom cost data is missing in the Optum© Clinformatics® DataMart
